p: Here we have shown, in summary, that mosquito-disseminated PPF has the potential to become a major tool for urban mosquito control and, consequently, for the prevention of mosquito-borne diseases. These findings might be equally relevant for rapidly spreading emerging arboviral infections, including Zika and chikungunya, and for better-established endemic pathogens, including dengue, West Nile, and Japanese encephalitis viruses. Cluster-randomized, multi-site controlled trials are now necessary to provide stronger evidence for (or against) these hypotheses [ 46]. We plan to conduct one such trial in the context of the Brazilian dengue control program, which recently recommended considering our approach for inclusion in national guidelines [ 51]. Based on the present findings, we anticipate that randomized controlled trials will show that mosquito-disseminated PPF can develop into a new, crucial means for improving global public health.
